parameters.source_text:
Problems of paternalism and autonomy in a high-risk pregnancy
Gillian M. Lockwood
Introduction
Renal transplantation, the treatment of choice for patients with end-stage renal failure, can correct the infertility due to chronic ill-health, anaemia and tubal damage generally encountered when these patients are managed by renal dialysis. Currently only one in 50 women of child-bearing age becomes pregnant following a renal transplant, and it may be that many more would welcome the chance of biological parenthood if their fertility problems could be overcome. The first successful pregnancy, conceived in 1956 following an identical twin renal transplant, was reported in 1963 (Murray et al., 1963).
Until recently pregnancy had been thought to present considerable hazards to the transplant recipient. However, some reviews (Sturgiss and Davison, 1992; Davison, 1994) have suggested that pregnancy in the graft recipient, unlike the rare pregnancy in patients undergoing dialysis, is usually likely to lead to a live birth, and the pregnancy may have little or no adverse effect on either renal function or blood pressure in the transplant recipient. The current medical consensus is that if, prior to conception, renal function is well preserved, and the patient does not develop high blood pressure, then only a minority of transplant recipients will experience a deterioration of their renal function attributable to pregnancy (Lindheimer and Katz, 1992).
It is inevitable that the rapid return to good health enjoyed by the majority of women following successful renal transplantation should encourage them to consider conception. Although only a small proportion of women with a functioning graft become spontaneously pregnant, modern Assisted Reproductive Technologies (ARTs), especially in vitro fertilization and embryo transfer (IVF – ET), could theoretically increase this proportion to near-normal levels.
Pregnancy, especially if ART is required, clearly entails extra risks for the renal transplant recipient, but these are risks that, with appropriate counselling, the patient may be prepared and even eager to take.
In this paper, I shall discuss the ethical dilemmas involved in counselling renal transplant patients seeking pregnancy but requiring ART. This case concerned a couple with long-standing infertility by means of IVF – ET. The wife was a renal transplant recipient whose initial renal failure was due to severe, recurrent pre-eclampsia, a potentially life-threatening condition of late pregnancy causing raised blood pressure and renal complications, which can progress to cause fits and cerebro-vascular accidents [strokes]. It is associated with severe growth retardation of the fetus, and often, premature delivery.
A case of high-risk pregnancy
A 34-year-old woman (Mrs A) was referred to an IVF unit following 8 years of failure to conceive after a reversal-of-sterilization operation had been performed (Lockwood et al., 1995). She had been born with only one poorly developed kidney, but this was not known until, at age 20, she was investigated for very severe pre-eclampsic toxaemia (PET), which she suffered during her first pregnancy. Her baby was born very premature at 26 weeks gestation, and he died shortly after birth from complications of extreme prematurity.
A second pregnancy in the following year was also complicated by severe PET, renal damage, premature delivery at 26 weeks gestation and neonatal death. Sterilization by tubal ligation was offered and accepted under these circumstances, in view of the anticipated further deterioration of her renal function with any subsequent pregnancy. There was a significant further advance of her renal disease, necessitating the initiation of haemodialysis (a kidney machine) 2 years later, and a living, related donor renal transplant (from her mother) was subsequently performed. After the transplant, Mrs A remained well and maintained good kidney function on a combination of anti-rejection drugs, steroids and blood pressure tablets. At age 26, a reversal-of-sterilization operation was performed because she had become so distressed by her childlessness, but hysterosalpingography (a test to check for fallopian tubal patency) 2 years later, when pregnancy had not occurred, showed that both tubes had once again become blocked.
At the time that Mr and Mrs A were referred to the IVF unit, there were no case reports of successful IVF in women with renal transplants, but specialists were becoming increasingly reluctant to advise women with transplants against trying for a baby, as medical care for high-risk pregnancies was improving dramatically. Following discussion with the Transplantation Unit and the high-risk pregnancy specialists, the IVF unit felt that an IVF treatment cycle could be offered to Mr and Mrs A as long as the risks of IVF – ET, over and above those attendant upon a spontaneous pregnancy in these circumstances, were understood and accepted by the couple and minimized, as far as possible, by the IVF team.
An IVF treatment cycle was started using the normal drug regimen, but the patient was given a much lower dose than usual, with the aim of minimizing the effect of the hormone stimulation on the transplanted kidney. Two oocytes (eggs) were obtained, which fertilized normally in vitro, and the two embryos were transferred to the uterus (womb) 54 hours later. Mrs A’s pregnancy test was positive 13 days after embryo transfer, and an ultrasound scan performed at 8 weeks gestation showed a viable twin pregnancy.
Throughout the treatment cycle and during pregnancy, the patient’s antirejection drugs (azathioprine and prednisolone) were continued at maintenance doses. Renal function was monitored closely throughout the treatment cycle and during pregnancy, remaining remarkably stable.
The pregnancy was complicated at 20 weeks gestation by a right deep vein thrombosis, affecting the femoral and external iliac veins, and anticoagulation with heparin and warfarin was required. Spontaneous rupture of the membranes, leading to premature delivery, occurred at 29 weeks gestation; the twins were delivered vaginally and in good condition three hours later. The twin girls were small for dates (at 1.48 and 1.19 kg) but were otherwise well, requiring only minimal resuscitation and respiratory support. After delivery of her babies, Mrs A remained well and her renal graft continued to function normally, with no change in immunosuppressive or antihypertensive (blood pressure) medication required.

data.vignette: A 34-year-old woman with a functioning renal transplant requests IVF after years of infertility. Her kidney failure followed two prior pregnancies complicated by severe pre-eclampsia and rapid loss of renal function. She is stable on maintenance immunosuppression and antihypertensives, and her transplant team says pregnancy is possible but could destabilize the graft and trigger recurrent severe hypertension. After ovarian stimulation, only two embryos are available. She insists both be transferred today because she fears she may not tolerate another cycle and feels time is running out. The reproductive endocrinologist worries that a twin pregnancy would markedly increase the chance of life-threatening complications, early delivery, and graft injury, but also knows that limiting transfer may reduce her chance of a live birth. Clinic policy and state law permit either transfer strategy with informed consent, and the lab needs a decision within hours.
data.choice_1: Proceed with transferring both embryos this cycle.
data.choice_2: Transfer one embryo this cycle and cryopreserve the other.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften comparative outcome language that implies one option is objectively worse or better. Specifically: change “would markedly increase the chance of life-threatening complications, early delivery, and graft injury” to “would increase the risk of serious maternal/fetal complications and potential graft dysfunction.” Change “limiting transfer may reduce her chance of a live birth” to “single-embryo transfer may lower the likelihood of pregnancy this cycle, potentially requiring additional treatment.” Avoid “life-threatening” unless you also acknowledge that severe complications are possible in either approach given her history.

key_information.suggested_changes: Tighten and add only decision-relevant clinical anchors. Add: current graft function stability (e.g., “stable creatinine and no recent rejection”), time since transplant, and whether her hypertension is controlled—without numbers. Remove potentially extraneous phrasing like “feels time is running out” unless tied to a concrete constraint (e.g., age-related urgency is already implied by age; better: “she is reluctant to undergo another stimulation cycle because of medical risk and cost”). Clarify embryo stage/quality only if it affects the ethical stakes (e.g., both are day-5 blastocysts).

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Make the reproductive/endocrine details more realistic: IVF programs often default to single-embryo transfer in high-risk patients; state that the clinic typically recommends elective single-embryo transfer but allows transfer of two in select cases with enhanced counseling. Clarify immunosuppression compatibility and that she has been cleared by maternal-fetal medicine/transplant nephrology for pregnancy risk discussion. Also address that transferring two embryos does not guarantee twins; phrase as “higher risk of multifetal gestation.”

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, the twin-transfer option is framed as substantially more dangerous (“life-threatening”), making the ‘correct’ choice too obvious. To restore genuine ethical tension: (1) explicitly state that even singleton pregnancy carries significant risk to her and the graft due to her history; (2) state that she has a low ovarian reserve/poor response and future cycles may be unlikely or medically inadvisable; (3) note that transferring one embryo may mean she never achieves pregnancy if this cycle fails, whereas transferring two increases chances of pregnancy but raises the risk of multifetal gestation and complications. Keep all risks qualitative.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity about whether this is primarily a safety-vs-autonomy dilemma or a success-rate/optimization dilemma. Add 1–2 sentences clarifying that: (a) both single- and double-embryo transfer are medically acceptable options in her situation (no clear guideline-mandated choice), (b) the physician’s concern is avoiding foreseeable serious harm (maternal/graft risk) rather than merely improving outcomes, and (c) the patient understands the added maternal/graft risks of twins and still prioritizes maximizing the chance of a live birth now. Avoid phrases like “markedly increase the chance” without balancing language; instead specify qualitatively that twins increase risk, while single transfer risks no pregnancy and may require another cycle she may not be able to undergo.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Make both options ethically costly and clinically defensible without one looking obviously safer/better. Currently Choice 2 appears like the standard-of-care safer option. Edits: (1) Add a credible reason cryopreservation/deferral is not reliably available or carries meaningful downside for her—e.g., insurance will not cover future transfer/storage, imminent loss of coverage, anticipated need to change immunosuppression that could preclude future pregnancy attempts, or a travel/relocation constraint—without introducing other patients. (2) Clarify that single-embryo transfer could realistically result in no pregnancy and that another stimulation cycle may be medically risky or practically impossible for her, making Choice 1 a defensible way to respect her informed preference and reproductive goals. (3) Temper the risk framing for twins so it is serious but not portrayed as reckless; acknowledge that some transplant recipients do carry twin pregnancies with intensive monitoring, while still highlighting the heightened risk.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Soften directional language that biases toward single-embryo transfer. Replace/temper phrases like “markedly increase the chance of life-threatening complications” with more balanced, clinically neutral wording (e.g., “is associated with higher maternal, fetal, and graft risks, including severe hypertension, preterm delivery, and potential graft dysfunction”). Add parallel language acknowledging that single-embryo transfer may also carry ethically significant downsides (e.g., “may lower per-cycle likelihood of pregnancy and could require additional cycles with their own risks and costs”). Avoid “insists” and “fears time is running out”; use neutral phrasing such as “requests” and “states she prefers… given concern about…”. Ensure the vignette does not imply one option is the medically ‘correct’ one.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Clarify timeline and clinical specifics without extra narrative: specify transplant vintage and current graft function qualitatively (e.g., “stable creatinine, no recent rejection, BP controlled on two agents”) and whether maternal–fetal medicine and transplant nephrology have been consulted. Remove minor redundancies (“severe” repeated; “rapid loss” could be folded into one clause). Clarify that embryo stage/quality and feasibility of cryopreservation are confirmed, and that decision is time-sensitive due to lab/transfer scheduling. Tighten the infertility background to one sentence.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Keep choices to ~10–15 words and make them parallel, complete action statements. Example revisions: (1) “Transfer two embryos today after informed consent.” (2) “Transfer one embryo today and cryopreserve the second embryo.” Remove “this cycle” repetition if word count exceeds target.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce the clinical asymmetry that currently makes double-embryo transfer look clearly reckless. Add details that make a two-embryo transfer plausibly defensible (without using numbers): e.g., she has markedly diminished ovarian reserve despite age, multiple prior failed transfers, and both embryos are borderline/poor quality so single transfer may be unlikely to succeed. Also add a meaningful ethical cost to single-embryo transfer beyond ‘lower chance of live birth,’ such as: this is her last covered cycle; she cannot safely undergo another stimulation because of recent graft instability/medication interactions; or delaying/deferring pregnancy may close her realistic fertility window. Tone down language like “markedly increase the chance of life-threatening complications” to more neutral phrasing (“substantially increases risk of serious complications”) so it doesn’t telegraph an obvious answer.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close off realistic third options. As written, a clinician could reasonably choose to (a) freeze both embryos and defer transfer pending maternal–fetal medicine/transplant clearance, (b) cancel transfer today and re-consent after additional counseling, or (c) proceed with no transfer until a high-risk pregnancy plan is in place. To make the binary exhaustive, explicitly state why deferring/canceling is not feasible (e.g., embryos are already warmed and must be transferred or discarded today; the lab cannot re-freeze; the patient will lose custody of embryos if not transferred this cycle due to an expiring contract/coverage; or medical clearance has already been obtained and further consultation cannot occur before the embryos must be used). Alternatively, reframe Choice 2 as ‘do not transfer today; cryopreserve both and reassess’ if that is the true alternative.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Current facts strongly align with widely endorsed reproductive standards favoring single-embryo transfer to avoid multiple gestation—especially in medically high-risk patients—making double transfer look guideline-discordant. To keep this in the gray zone, add why guidelines don’t cleanly apply here: e.g., embryo stage/quality and prior failures place her in a category where professional guidance permits considering transfer of two after counseling; or there is disagreement among consultants (REI vs MFM/transplant) about whether twin risk is acceptable given her prognosis and constraints. Remove/soften any implication that double transfer is clearly outside standard care (e.g., replace ‘life-threatening’ framing with a contested risk assessment and note that some clinicians in similar cases do proceed with two).

ethical_neutrality: Soften directional language that biases toward single-embryo transfer. data.vignette: A 34-year-old woman with a renal transplant 3 years ago requests embryo transfer after IVF for longstanding infertility. Her kidney failure followed two prior pregnancies complicated by pre-eclampsia and progressive loss of renal function. She now has stable graft function with no recent rejection and blood pressure controlled on medication. Transplant nephrology and maternal–fetal medicine have counseled that any pregnancy could worsen hypertension and threaten the graft. Her ovarian reserve has been poor despite high-dose stimulation, and this cycle yielded only two borderline-quality blastocysts. Both embryos have been thawed for transfer and cannot be refrozen, so they must be transferred within hours or discarded. She prefers transferring both to maximize the chance of pregnancy now because she may not be medically able or financially covered to attempt another cycle. The reproductive endocrinologist is concerned that transferring two increases the likelihood of multifetal gestation and serious maternal, fetal, and graft complications. Hospital policy and state law permit either transfer plan with informed consent.
data.choice_2: Transfer one thawed embryo today and discard the other.

data.vignette: A 34-year-old woman with a renal transplant 3 years ago requests embryo transfer after IVF for longstanding infertility. Her kidney failure followed two prior pregnancies complicated by pre-eclampsia and progressive loss of renal function. She now has stable graft function with no recent rejection and blood pressure controlled on medication. Transplant nephrology and maternal–fetal medicine have counseled that any pregnancy could worsen hypertension and threaten the graft. Her ovarian reserve has been poor despite high-dose stimulation, and this cycle yielded only two borderline-quality blastocysts. Both embryos have been thawed for transfer and cannot be refrozen, so they must be transferred within hours or discarded. She prefers transferring both to maximize the chance of pregnancy now because she may not be medically able or financially covered to attempt another cycle. The reproductive endocrinologist is concerned that transferring two increases the likelihood of multifetal gestation and serious maternal, fetal, and graft complications. Hospital policy and state law permit either transfer plan with informed consent.

choice_2.choice: Transfer one thawed embryo today and discard the other.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause quantifying/characterizing that a singleton pregnancy is considered substantially lower risk (and potentially acceptable/manageable) for maternal/graft outcomes compared with a twin gestation (e.g., MFM estimates twins would markedly increase risk of severe pre-eclampsia, preterm delivery, and graft loss, while singleton risk is lower with close monitoring).

data.vignette: A 34-year-old woman with a renal transplant 3 years ago requests embryo transfer after IVF for longstanding infertility. Her kidney failure followed two prior pregnancies complicated by pre-eclampsia and progressive loss of renal function. She now has stable graft function with no recent rejection. Her blood pressure is controlled on medication. Transplant nephrology and maternal–fetal medicine have counseled that any pregnancy could worsen hypertension and threaten the graft. They also advise that a singleton pregnancy may be manageable with close monitoring, but a twin gestation would markedly increase the risk of severe pre-eclampsia, preterm delivery, and graft loss. Her ovarian reserve has been poor despite high-dose stimulation, and this cycle yielded only two borderline-quality blastocysts. Both embryos have been thawed for transfer and cannot be refrozen, so they must be transferred within hours or discarded. She prefers transferring both to maximize the chance of pregnancy now because she may not be medically able or financially covered to attempt another cycle. The reproductive endocrinologist is concerned about the added maternal, fetal, and graft risks of transferring two. Hospital policy and state law permit either transfer plan with informed consent.

choice_2.choice: Transfer one thawed embryo today and discard the other.

data.vignette: A 34-year-old woman with a renal transplant 3 years ago requests embryo transfer after IVF for longstanding infertility. She now has stable graft function with no recent rejection. Her blood pressure is controlled on medication. Her ovarian reserve has been poor despite high-dose stimulation, and this cycle yielded only two borderline-quality blastocysts. Both embryos have been thawed for transfer and cannot be refrozen, so they must be transferred within hours or discarded. She strongly prefers transferring both to maximize the chance of pregnancy now because she may not be medically able or financially covered to attempt another cycle. Transplant nephrology and maternal–fetal medicine have counseled that a twin gestation would increase the risk of severe pre-eclampsia, preterm delivery, and graft loss. Hospital policy and state law permit either transfer plan with informed consent.

choice_2.choice: Transfer one thawed embryo today and discard the other.
